claim.text: Hospital patients with views of trees recover faster
claim.claim: Hospital patients with views of trees recover faster than those without

results.summary: This claim is supported by the landmark 1984 study by Roger Ulrich published in Science.
results.detail: Roger Ulrich's 1984 study 'View through a window may influence recovery from surgery' published in Science (Vol. 224, pp. 420-421) found that hospital patients recovering from gallbladder surgery who had views of trees had shorter hospital stays (7.96 days vs 8.70 days), required fewer analgesic doses, and had fewer negative nurse evaluations compared to patients whose windows faced a brick wall. This study has been widely replicated and is foundational in evidence-based healthcare design.
sources: Ulrich, R.S. (1984). View through a window may influence recovery from surgery. Science, 224(4647), 420-421

claim.text: Office workers with plants report 15% higher productivity
claim.claim: Office workers with plants report 15% higher productivity

results.summary: Unable to verify due to lack of web search access in this session.
results.detail: Web search and web fetch tools are not available in this session, preventing verification of the 15% productivity claim. This statistic is commonly cited in discussions of biophilic design and appears to originate from research by Dr. Chris Knight and colleagues at the University of Exeter, but I cannot confirm the exact figure or methodology without access to search tools.
